Healthy tomato leaf: The tomato leaf is in healthy condition, don't have to do anything.
Bacterial spot: Remove infected leaves, use copper-based bactericides, and ensure proper spacing for air circulation.
Early blight: Remove affected leaves, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products, and practice crop rotation.
Late blight: Remove and destroy infected plants, use fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil, and avoid overhead watering.
Leaf mold: Increase air circulation, avoid overhead watering, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays, and prune affected leaves.
Septoria leaf spot: Remove infected leaves, apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb, and practice crop rotation.
Two-spotted spider mite: Use insecticidal soap or miticides, introduce natural predators like ladybugs, and maintain adequate moisture levels.
Target Spot: Remove and destroy infected plant debris, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb, and practice crop rotation.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus: Control whiteflies with insecticidal soap or neem oil, use reflective mulches, and plant resistant varieties.
Tomato mosaic virus: Remove and destroy infected plants, disinfect tools and hands after handling plants, and plant resistant varieties.
